comments.author: Byron Harper

comments.text:
When one scare tactic doesn't work, go to the next one. Their play book 
Rolodex has all of the formula one-liners and catch phrases. Republics just 
can't help themselves. Use of race bating code language ("quotas", "reverse 
discrimination", "busing") is so reflexive for them that they just start 
mindlessly repeating them even in non-race related issues. There just is no 
way to turn wrong into right. Fool us once, twice, three times...enough 
already!﻿
comments.author: SynchroTotal

comments.text:
Tom Ricks' argument is naive and illogical.  It's amazing how many people 
are applauding him for this statement.

Hundreds of security and private contractors were killed in Iraq & 
Afghanistan.  Their deaths were not reported because they held low-profile, 
standard operating jobs.  Thousands of military personel were lost in those 
wars too -- but their deaths were not reported on the news.

So why did Fox News report ("hype") the Benghazi story?  They reported it 
because an international assassination had occurred -- it was a 'target 
killing.'  A US Ambassador is a very high-profile position, plain and 
simple.  Only five other Ambassadors in American history have ever been 
assassinated, making the Benghazi story an enormous story.  The 
international community certainly knows this.

Tom Ricks might as well complain that America was shell-shocked by the JFK 
assassination -- but weren't EQUALLY shocked over the Americans who 
suffered from the Agent Orange disaster.
In a very simple way, one life holds far more gravity than the other lives.
That is not to say that, "one is more important than the other", but a 
political leader holds more significance & implication than a 1st 
Lieutenant in the Army.

Common sense, people.  Simple, long-forgotten... common sense.﻿

comments.text:
TO ALL YOU FOX HATERS AND THE YOUNG TURKS ESPECIALLY

As reported by US News, The Wall Street Journal, and The Pew Research 
Center:

"In a stunning rejection of network news and nightly news anchors, cable 
news, driven by the Fox News Channel and mouthy Bill O'Reilly, is now the 
top most trusted source -- by a mile. In a new poll from Boston's Suffolk 
University, more than a quarter of the nation says Fox is tops when it 
comes to who they trust the most, and O'Reilly is the most believable.

"The key finding is that network news is dying. Some 28 percent of likely 
voters say that they trust Fox News the most, followed by CNN at 18 
percent. After that, the trust in TV news nose dives. NBC was third, at 10 
percent, MSNBC fourth at 7 percent, CBS and ABC tied at fifth with just 6 
percent."

Viewer Demographics:
Fox News: 39% Republican, 33% Democratic, 22% Independent
CNN: 18% Republican, 51% Democratic, 23% Independent
MSNBC: 18% Republican, 45% Democratic, 27% Independent﻿

comments.text:
The point was, the story was getting way more hype than it deserved. We 
don't trumpet every murder on the news for months. We don't trumpet every 
fire fight on the news for months either. Benghazi was a big deal, at the 
time. Not any more.

comments.text: BUT, BUT BENGHAZI!!!!!!!!!!
comments.author: bordy217

comments.text:
Mr. Ricks demolished the Fox anchor debate-wise, but at the same time I'm 
not sure I agree with the substance of his points. It wasn't "big" in terms 
of casualties, it was a big deal, I think, because the administration 
misled the public about it. It's like saying a murder isn't "big" and 
shouldn't be covered because people die every day. I'm by no means on Fox's 
side in general but this story troubled me when it happened.
